item.title: A Personal Note From Our Founder – Hindenburg Research
item.description: As I’ve shared with family, friends and our team since late last year, I have made the decision to disband Hindenburg Research. The plan has been to wind up after we finished the pipeline of ideas we were working on. And as of the last Ponzi cases we just completed and are sharing with regulators, that day is today.

item.title: furialog
item.description: I think about music in years. 2024 was the first year in a long time that I didn't have anything to do with Spotify Wrapped, but that was never why I thought about music in years, and certainly never how. I like my music data to tell me stories about music not about graphic design, and in verifiable numbers not templated snarkiness. I want to stand at the end of one year and the brink of another and think clearly about how I've been listening, and thus living, and expansively about how I might.

item.title: Beating cuBLAS in Single-Precision General Matrix Multiplication
item.description: In this blog post, we’ll walk through an implementation of the SGEMM (Single-precision GEneral Matrix Multiply) operation defined as C := alpha*A*B + beta*C. We will review three different kernels, each optimized for specific matrix size problems. Our final implementation is optimized for Ampere architecture and outperforms cuBLAS on wide range of matrix size problems.

item.description: Since 2021, TCL has been investing in an intriguing screen technology called NXTPAPER: an LCD panel that attempts to simulate paper to be less harsh on human...

item.title: The Immutable Badge - A Thought Experiment
item.description: Imagine an immutable, hidden badge is attached to you. You cannot remove, transfer, or modify it. However, no one can see it without your knowledge and consent. This is a thought experiment about the ultimate biometrics identifier.

item.title: Real Semantic Versioning
item.description: Semantic version (SemVer) is possibly the most widely used software versioning scheme. We all know how SemVer works: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. The first number is for backward-incompatible changes, the middle number is for backward-compatible new features, and the last number is for backward-compatible bugfixes. …it’s a shame how infrequently it actually seems to be used this way! Backward incompatible changes on minor versions happen all the time. By far the most common example are deprecations, even amongst libraries that claim to follow SemVer.

item.title: all kpis are derivatives of revenue or cost
item.description: Every metric, objective or goal should be driving revenue or reducing cost. If it isn’t, it’s not something a business, product or team should be pursuing.

item.title: Beating OpenBLAS in FP32 Matrix Multiplication
item.description: In this tutorial we’ll step-by-step optimize multi-threaded FP32 matrix multiplication on CPU outperforming OpenBLAS on wide range of matrix sizes. The algorithm follows the BLIS design and is implemented in simple, scalable C code parallelized with OpenMP. Tags: High-performance GEMM on CPU. Fast SGEMM in C. High-performance matrix multiplication on CPU. SGEMM Optimization on CPU.

item.title: The Shuffler Really is Broken: Finding the Best Method for Shuffling Cubes — Lucky Paper
item.description: The conventional Cube wisdom may be to shuffle a cube as a group, exchanging piles randomly around the table, but in this case the shuffler is in fact broken! Here's why and how to shuffle your cube the way you deserve.

item.title: Cohesive Digests for Ints and Floats
item.description: On developing sdxtra I encountered a problem to calculate cohesive digests for numeric values, agnostic to their types. This post is a brief summary of the solution I came up with.

item.title: The Scaling Paradox — Toby Ord
item.description: AI capabilities have improved remarkably quickly, fuelled by the explosive scale-up of resources being used to train the leading models. But if you examine the scaling laws that inspired this rush, they actually show extremely poor returns to scale. What’s going on?

item.title: Effortless tests with cached stubs
item.description: Imagine you have just written a complex piece of code (maybe an agent?) that interacts with several APIs and possibly uses large language models (LLMs). item.title: Tracking and Personalizing Connections – Chris Woody Woodruff
item.description: In the world of socket programming, managing client sessions is where the magic happens. It’s what transforms a basic connection into a personalized, memorable experience. Whether you’re building a chat application, a multiplayer game, or a real-time dashboard, tracking and managing client sessions is the secret sauce that keeps users engaged and coming back for more.

item.title: If You Ever See This Speed Sign, You're Probably Going To Die - The Autopian
item.description: The Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) is widely considered to be a dry and unemotional document. Published by the Department of Transportation, it outlines the basic specifications of all the street signs you could expect to see out on roads and highways across the United States. Most are familiar, but if you dive […]

item.description: Cosine similarity - the duct tape of AI. Convenient but often misused. Let's find out how to use it better.
